history.content:
EDIT: EECS C106A and C106B totally slipped my mind since they aren't relevant to my research specifically, but, if you're interested in building prostheses then I think they'd probably be pretty useful as well.

I do research that involves implanted electronic sensors, so I suppose I'm as qualified to answer this as anyone else here. Assuming you're in a position to take 105 and 120 starting next semester, I would do just that, and maybe take a neurobiology class too if you're so inclined (it should be noted that going from electronics -> biology is a lot easier than going from biology -> electronics in skillset, so taking biology courses as an undergrad is purely up to you). From there, you'll be able to see where exactly you'll want to focus (i.e. in the signal processing, the circuits, or the biology) and have the requisite knowledge to get involved in substantive research in one of the many biomedical-focused labs on campus. A list of professors working in this area includes Jose Carmena, Michel Maharbiz (I work in this group), Rikky Muller (teaches EE 140 on occasion), Jan Rabaey (used to teach EECS 151), Ana Arias, Miki Lustig (teaches EE 123), Kris Pister (teaches EE 140), and Bernhard Boser (teaches EE 140 and graduate analog classes), as well as other circuits professors that are more peripherally involved (e.g. Elad Alon, Ali Niknejad). It's very likely that I forgot a bunch of people in listing this, so that should show that there are plenty of avenues to get involved. Obviously, doing research is the best way to look good on a PhD application and figure out if you really want a PhD, but, yes, courses will allow you to better understand what you want to do research on. 

Relevant courses after EE 105 and EE 120 and when to take them (disclaimer: this is only for EECS, supplement these with whatever biology courses you like best):

Circuits: EE 140 and EECS 151 will make you very productive, but they are both extremely challenging and can be taken in graduate school. If you were choosing between the two, I'd say 151 is more important. If you happen to take 140, Prof. Muller teaches a possibly very useful special topics class on circuits for bioengineering, so that could be cool (but can also be left for graduate school). 

MEMS and Fabrication: For some groups, EE 147 and/or EE 143 are very useful (you'll be able to tell after doing a bit of reading and work).

Signal Processing: EE 123 and EECS 126 should definitely be taken as an undergrad. The last third or so of 126 is considered graduate material at other universities, but this should not intimidate you, since it is a very well-run course. If you're really into MRI, you can take EE C145B. Other relevant courses like EECS 127 and CS 189 can be taken depending on how theoretical your work is / how much machine learning can ease your problem solving process. EE 128 is good to take with 140, if you choose to take it, since 140's project (designing an amplifier) essentially is an application of control theory concepts.

And that essentially covers the essentials from an EECS perspective. As for the other classes you mentioned, CS 170 is good to take if you're interested in it, although it probably won't make much of a difference to your research. CS 162 is not particularly relevant, but definitely take it if you plan on hedging your bets between a PhD and software engineering (something similar goes for 189 and 182). Good luck!

I want to pursue a PhD in BioE/BME in neuroengineering (electronic sensor research for improving prostheses or research on helping the brain dead) and I am trying to figure out what would be some beneficial upper division classes to take for the rest of undergrad. Does anyone have any recommendations on classes and/or research opportunities at Cal?


So far I've looked at taking EE 105, EE 120, EE 123, EE 126, CS 162, CS 170, CS 189, and CS 182 along with neurobiology classes from MCB.

Any advice helps!
history.subject: PhD Preparation/Recommended Undergrad Courses
